description.text: On this image from Phoenix P. Works we see a Hindu woman opening an envelope while seated on a wooden armchair.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Design sample: Sitting woman opening an envelope

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: On this image from Phoenix P. Works we see a Hindu woman opening an envelope while seated on a wooden armchair.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This woman, probably in her mid-twenties, wears a relatively modest, yet elegant yellow sari. Her hair, partially tied in a plaid, hangs over her shoulder, down to her hips and over the left backrest. She wears jewellery, indicating middleclassness, two golden bangles on each arm, a necklace made of pearls, small earrings and a nosering on the left. She looks at the letter as if she awaits a personal message (a love letter?).() (cb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: For all that women are objectified by the male gaze, many images avoid overt sexualization, depicting women far removed from the bath with its seductive possibilities and away from mirrors reflecting surface beauty. Women instead demonstrate their own, independent connections to the outside world made through telephone lines, radio broadcasts, books and magazines, their own writing, or letters received. Women here have their own thoughts, record them in private, and transmit them outside the home. In all of these, women engage as individuals, neither under the direct control of their husbands nor as members of a married couple. At the same time, in all of these images, women are cut off from the physical presence of other women; they might talk or write to women outside the home, but in daily life the modern women was on her own. This might have made her free from a domineering mother-in-law, but it also left her devoid of the support offered by female friends and kin. The autonomy offered in these images, in other words, combines financial dependence on men with individual expression, and freedom of action with social isolation. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Finally and perhaps most interestingly, images of the modern home also promised women autonomy. In all the images discussed thus far, women appear on their own, free to spend their time as they please, whether reading a book, talking with friends, or sitting quietly in a chair doing nothing. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In these images no children demand attention, no husband asks to be served, no older women intervene to make decisions; the ubiquitous mother-in-law to which a young wife would have to give deference, has been banished from the scene. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: These (ID's 109789, 109784) are specifically not textile labels, but image samples from a catalogue from a publisher (from Ahmedabad) who provides such images to clients for whatever purpose they may seek. The publisher call themselves ticket printers. (ys)

related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/104/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-14, online essay "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux" by Sabika Gadihoke (gs)

related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/95/index.html, last accessed 2011-04-13, essay "Modernity at Home: Leisure, Autonomy and the New Woman in India" by Abigail McGowan (gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 1995. "Imperial Leather: Race, Gender, and Sexuality in the Colonial Conquest" New York: Routledge, 216-217. (gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 2001. “Soft Soaping Empire: Commodity Racism and Imperial Advertising” in Double Crossings: Madness, Sexuality and Imperialism. Vancouver, Canada: Ronsdale. (gs)
related literature: Sivulka, Julianne 1998. "Soap, Sex and Cigarettes: A Cultural History of Advertising". Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Co. (gs)
related literature: Storey, John 1999. "Cultural Consumption and Everyday Life". New York: Oxford University Press. (gs)
related literature: Uberoi, Patricia 2003. “Chicks, Kids and Couples: The Nation in Calendar Art,” in India, a National Culture?, ed. Geeti Sen. New Delhi: Sage Publications. (gs)
essay "Consumption and identity: Imagining ‘Everyday Life’ Through Popular Visual Culture" by Sandria B. Freitag
online essay "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux" by Sabika Gadihoke
essay "Modernity at Home: Leisure, Autonomy and the New Woman in India" by Abigail McGowan

These (ID's 109789, 109784) are specifically not textile labels, but image samples from a catalogue from a publisher (from Ahmedabad) who provides such images to clients for whatever purpose they may seek. The publisher call themselves ticket printers.

For all that women are objectified by the male gaze, many images avoid overt sexualization, depicting women far removed from the bath with its seductive possibilities and away from mirrors reflecting surface beauty. Women instead demonstrate their own, independent connections to the outside world made through telephone lines, radio broadcasts, books and magazines, their own writing, or letters received. Women here have their own thoughts, record them in private, and transmit them outside the home. In all of these, women engage as individuals, neither under the direct control of their husbands nor as members of a married couple. At the same time, in all of these images, women are cut off from the physical presence of other women; they might talk or write to women outside the home, but in daily life the modern women was on her own. This might have made her free from a domineering mother-in-law, but it also left her devoid of the support offered by female friends and kin. The autonomy offered in these images, in other words, combines financial dependence on men with individual expression, and freedom of action with social isolation.

Finally and perhaps most interestingly, images of the modern home also promised women autonomy. In all the images discussed thus far, women appear on their own, free to spend their time as they please, whether reading a book, talking with friends, or sitting quietly in a chair doing nothing.

This woman, probably in her mid-twenties, wears a relatively modest, yet elegant yellow sari. Her hair, partially tied in a plaid, hangs over her shoulder, down to her hips and over the left backrest. She wears jewellery, indicating middleclassness, two golden bangles on each arm, a necklace made of pearls, small earrings and a nosering on the left. She looks at the letter as if she awaits a personal message (a love letter?).

In these images no children demand attention, no husband asks to be served, no older women intervene to make decisions; the ubiquitous mother-in-law to which a young wife would have to give deference, has been banished from the scene.
